properties.name: Colluseam
properties.description: Posted by Landonmiles

properties.name: Colosseum
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesThe Flavian Amphitheatre (its real name) was begun in the year 72 A.D. under Vespianand inagurated by the emperor Titusin the year 80. The inaguration was a solem event that marked 100 days of festivities. The writer Dion Cassius relates that during these festivitties that some 2000 gladiators lost their lives. The amphitheater was finnaly completed by Emperor Domitiam The amphitheatre consists of four floors and can hold about 50,000 spectators. At the long ends of the arena, there were two entrances: the south-easternone was the "Libitinarian" Gate (The goddess of funerals) through wich the dead bodies of the gladiators would be carried out of. The entrance gate through wich gladiators would parade out of before the beginning of combats. "Ave, Caesar, Morituri te salutant" (Ceasar Those about to die salute you)

properties.name: Pantheon
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesRome, Italy

properties.name: Pantheon
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesRome, ItalyAfter the colosseum this is the most interesting and best preserved monument of agusta rome. It was constructed by the son-in-law of Agustus, Marco Agrippa, at the time of his third counsul. It is dedicated to the seven planetary divinities and is called Pantheon wich signifies "holiest" of "most sacred temple" Is is Beuatiful for the architectural conception of its circular plan and for the knowledgeable building technique used in the construction of the dome. The Pantheon is admirable for its grandure of line and the harmony of its parts. INside are the tombs of Italian Kings and the great Raphael

properties.name: Pyramids
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesgizaThe aincent pyramids have puzzled scientists for years. The 2,300,000 blocks ranging from 2 to 30 tons. Some blocks polished to 1/100th of an inch seem impossible for this primitive scociety to construct. What is known is that they were ment to honor their dead. Elaborate tunnels and passageways fill the tombs. Held in the center of the structures is the investments and sometimes self sacrificed servants. The reason for all of the material items is that it was beleived that they (along with the servants) would follow you in the afterlife.

properties.name: Saint Simon
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesHigh class luxury homes scatterd throughout a lush green well kept island that sports one of the nicest golf courses in America. It is a place of extreme luxury... to the point where even gasstations are dressed up to match the high society of that area. An expected downside to this place would be the haughty attitude of the residence but contrary to expectations they are very nice and friendly.

properties.name: St Agustine, Florida
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesaddressThe settlement at St. Agustine was born out of conflict for control of treasure route and savage passions of religions. In 1562, three years before Menendez Landong three French Ships under the command of Jean Ribult, a protestant, had explored the mouth of the St. Johns river near what is now Jacksonville. Ribaults second-in-command built a fort that is still there today to protect a small settlement of french protestants. When Menendez arrived his first move was to attack the french settlement. Menendez captured fort Caroline on Septembr 20th. He had a celebration for his victory that was on the day of St. Agustine so he named the newfound land accordingly

properties.name: The Circuses
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesRome had a love for horse racing that can be understood from the abundance of testimonies rich in details that have been passed down to us that give uis the spirit of these races that took place over 2000 years ago. Rome had four tracks or "Circuses". The most important being the Circus Maximus was of extremely aincent origin and had in any case aquired its basic facilities by 329 BC with the construston of permanent starting stalls, followed by the gradual development of the circut. The Circus has a long raised median known as a spina wich was decorated with oblisks, statues etc. It could seat 250,00 people. It had all modern convienences in terms of business services such as merchants, bars, and wine sellers. The competitors would have to race 7 laps (roughly a mile). One famous racer Diocles had won a total of 4450 races and won a forune worth around several million dolars

properties.name: The Vatican
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesVatican CityAfter Christianity was recognized by constantine the great the first basilica dedicated to St. Peter was built on this site. Around it were crowded other constructions of religious and civil character. Pope Leo IV, in order to defend the basilica wich contained the tomb of the Prince of the Apostles from bloody political battles had the whole area surrounded by a robust walll forming the so-called "Lion City". In the course of centures, other popes added new walls to the first one. The actual Vatican Site is almost totaly enclosed by a belt of walls constructed between 1550 and 1640 by pope Paul III, Pius V, and urban VIII. The Vatican is the smallest country in the world. It has its own currency and a small police force for an army.

properties.name: The Vittoriano
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesLocated on the slope of Capitoline hill this grandiose monument certainltly celebrated italian independance. It is certainly not in harmony with the atmosphere created in the past by the artists and urbanists for the Eternal City. Nevertheless it is an expression and a seal of the epoch of the Risorgimento and of artistic taste at the end of the ninteenth century. Inspired by Hellenistic forms in its slightlycurvilinear arcade. In the interior of the alter supporting the statue of the Goddess of Roma is the tomb of the Unknown Solider. In front of that are two groups of guilded bronze that represent "thought" and "action" the workers began in 1885 and finished in 1911

properties.name: Trevi Fountain
properties.description: Posted by LandonmilesThis is the masterpeice of Roman architect Nicolo Slavi Who Was Comissioned by the Florentine Pope Clement XII to systemize the already existing spring called Virgin Water. This name comes to us from an aincent tradition which tells about a young girl who showed the spring to some thirsty soliders. In 19 B.C. this water was brought to the Rome by Agrippa. He constructed an aquaduct twenty kilometers long to provide for his thermal baths. Slavi knew how to intelligently make use of the existing architecture of the minor fascade of the Palace of Poli dukes. He produced a marvelous fountain, turning to the Roman Sculptor Pitro Bracci for the mythical configuration.
